did.abstract: The Middletown Manuscripts Collection is an intentionally created collection of disparate manuscripts related to the history of Middletown, Connecticut.
The majority of this collection is 18th- and 19th-century documents from around the Middletown, Connecticut area, with some documents from the 17th- and 20th-centuries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Middletown Manuscripts Collection is an intentionally created collection of disparate manuscripts related to the history of Middletown, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The majority of this collection is 18th- and 19th-century documents from around the Middletown area, with some documents from the 17th- and 20th-centuries. Most of the documents contained in this collection are legal documents, such as deeds, petitions, issued tickets, bills, etc. There are documents about the railroad in Middletown, including the documents about the building process of the extension through Middletown. The shipping records in the collection include some information about the ships themselves, as well as some information about where they were coming from and who was part of the crew. There is a folder of financial information belonging to the Addis family, which is primarily a collection of bills for Miss Addis and all the purchases she made. Another folder has financial information related to the Doane family. There are two bound books in the collection. The first has very little written in it, but it includes some correspondence between father and son in the de Zeng family about financial issues. The second bound book is a detailed journal kept by Charles H. Neff about the discovery of Indian relics and old Indian settlements in and around the Middletown area.

did.unittitle: Page 5: Indian Localities about Portland, Conn.

scopecontent.p: Indian Hill, large settlement, noted for Indian relics, on the northwest side of the hill facing the Connecticut River, eastern side of the hill was used as a cemetery.

Indian Relics are found along the Connecticut River shore from Indian Hill down to a short distance below Worthingtons where a large elm tree stands. Indian relics are found all along the Connecticut River Bank from Indian Hill up through Wougock Meadow to Tayoutown.

There was once an Indian Settlement on the farm of George Palmer near the St. John Chapel. Several Indian relics have been found on the John Shepherd Farm. A few Indian relics have been found on a plowed lot belonging to Hudson Hale on the west side of the meadows opposite Palmer's knoll.

Several Indian relics have been found on a plowed lot belonging to Horace Wilcox bordering the meadow south of the lower wougouk meadow drain. A plowed piece of ground belonging to Nelson Shepherd a short distance south of the brook leading to the upper wougouk meadow drain and bordering the east side of the wougouk meadows is a fair collecting ground. Several Indian relics have been found on the Charles Abbey farm at Gildersleeve. There was once an Indian village off the John Worthington farm.

Several arrowheads were found during the summer of 1884 on a plowed field bordering the Pacoreset Road on the Joseph Hall farm. A few Indian relics have been found in the sands about Brush pond meadows.

Quite a number of Indian relics have been found on plowed ground in the vicinity of a brook running through the John McLeave farm at Pacouset in the vicinity of the Catholic Cemetery and back of old farm house. There was once an Indian Settlement along the bank of the Connecticut River between Pacouset Drain and Bodkin Rock at the head of the straits. A piece of ground was plowed in the fall of 1890 at the Land Hill Swamp.

A few Indian relics have been found on plowed ground bordering the north side of the Chester Hurlbut cranberry marsh at Bucktown, Portland, Conn. Quite a number of arrowheads have been picked up from time to time on plowed ground bordering Coxes Brook on the Samuel Hurlbut farm.

did.unittitle: Page 15: Indian Localities about Glastonbury, Conn.

scopecontent.p: Found a fine collecting ground in the fall of 1884 between the Rocky Hill Ferry Road and the road leading to the Steamboat dock. A large Indian village was once at Red Hill Couth Glastonbury just north of Roaring Brook and but a shout distance back from the Connecticut River.
From Red Hill up through Glastonbury many Indian relics can be found. Araubuc North Glastonbury, Conn is a good collecting locality.

A piece of plowed ground bordering the Roaring Brook at South Glastonbury, Conn directly across from the Charles Hall fields and mill and not far from the stone bridge is a fairly good collecting ground.

did.unittitle: Page 19: Indian Localities about Rocky Hill, Conn.

scopecontent.p: A few Indian relics have been found on the Connecticut River shore at Lower Rocky Hill directly opposite Toyoutown about the vicinity of where a brook empties in the Connecticut River.

did.unittitle: Page 21: Indian Localities about Cromwell, Conn.

scopecontent.p: There was once an Indian settlement on the bank of the Connecticut River at North Cromwell, Conn. but a short distance above the Breakwater and extending for several rods along the shore. A large number of Indian relics have been found on the Cromwell shore north of brook leading into the Connecticut River directly across from Indian Hill, Portland.

Found several Indian relics on what is known as the Neck. A few Indian relics have been found along the Connecticut River shore from the head of Willow Island down to the entrance to Little River Cromwell, Conn.
Found several Indian relics on a piece of ground that was plowed in the fall of 1895 close by the Henry Hall barn on Fir Neck Little River Meadows.

did.unittitle: Page 26: Indian Localities about Fairfield, Conn.

scopecontent.p: Several Indian relics have been found at a place known as the Point. Several Indian relics have been found on plowed ground bordering the Little River Meadows south of Tuttles Brickyard at what is called Gilberts Point.

did.unittitle: Page 29: Indian Localities about Middletown, Conn.

scopecontent.p: There was once a large Indian village on the of the Middletown Branch Railroad near the West River Bridge. A large factory is now built year 1897 on the old Indian village site at what for years was known as the Griffin Trotting Park near the West River bridge.
